div.p: 1. IV. Sunday.

Rising early I was enabled by an exertion to write before Breakfast half a Letter to my wife— Mr Patterson a Lawyer of Bath who was going to Concord, took my Letter with a promise that he would put it into the Post-Office at Haverhill— Several persons were introduced to me at Bath this Morning but I have no recollection of their names— There was a new Meeting-house, nearly finished, near Carleton’s, the house where we lodged, but there was no preaching in it yet— There was public worship about two Miles distant; but the Stage which was to take us on came, before the time of Service, and we came in it thro’ Lisbon to Littleton—17. Miles— The road as we approach the Mountains becoming less pleasant, and the Country over which we travel, wilder, and more unsettled— There were one man two women, and a little girl four years old, Strangers, fellow passengers with us in the Stage— The woman with the Child met her husband at Littleton, and they went on in the Stage. One drunken outside Passenger had been somewhat annoying before we left Bath; and on the road, but we saw no more of him after reaching Littleton— He arrived there about one O’Clock, and I proposed attending Public worship in the afternoon— But there was no Service at the Meeting-house (a new one) near our Inn, and it was too late to go to the nearest Church, upwards of two Miles distant. The house where we put up is kept by a man named Gibb, and is very comfortable. The village is neat, and there are several handsome and rather showy houses in it— After dinner, I took a walk of half an hour with Mr Davis, but the weather, chilly and raw, with rain drove us back to the house— In the Evening we had several visitors, Inhabitants of the town, well-educated and intelligent men, whose names, with the exception of Mr Eli, escape my Recollection.
2. V. Monday.— Franconia— The Profile— Dinner at Littleton— E. A. Crawford’s.

We went in a Waggon with a pair of Horses to the Franconia Notch— Saw the Profile or Old Man of the Mountain—distance 11 Miles— The region all round is mountainous and ranges of thick clouds were scudding along upon their Seeds— It was doubtful whether the Old Man would shew his face, which he often and capriciously veils in smoky vapours. He was however this day when we reached the spot from which he can be seen, perfectly bare, with a clear Sky, and presented a Profile and throat as distinct, as if it had issued from the hands of a Sculptor— We saw him for a quarter of an hour, from three different stands or points of view, two in the road over which we came, and one from the border of a smooth and placid Pond at the foot of the Mountain, and which is the Head of Merrimack river. Another Pond, about half a mile distant is the head of the Saco river. The Profile, is at the summit of a Mountain covered with wood, said to be about 1200 feet above the surface of the Pond at which we stood. The Mountain on one side ascends in an Elliptic curve, not apparently very steep— The descent from the top is precipitous and the Profile projects over the nearly perpendicular side of the rock below— It shews a curly forehead, Homeric nose, lips, chin, cheek, beard and throat with the prominent Adam’s Apple; but not the back part of the head, nor the cylinder of the skull— Its appearance, relatively to the Mass of the Mountain is very diminutive, as if to exhibit an illustration of the contrast between the grandeur of Nature and the littleness of man. It stands like a human head, looking out from the hollow of the Mountain, reflecting upon the sublime Scenery before it, and meditating upon the omnipotence of the Creator— It strikes you as if the mountain itself was instinct with life—teeming with intelligence, gifted with the faculty of Speech and on the point of proclaiming with a voice of Thunder, the Majesty of God.
We returned immediately to Littleton; stopping as we had done when going at the half-way house; where were the New-Hampshire Iron works— We had not time to visit them, but saw several specimens of Iron Ore—and had a full view of the hill called after the name of La Fayette— At Noon we went up on the top of the Tower of the Meeting-House at Littleton from which there is a fine view of all the mountainous region around. We saw the top of Mount Washington, the highest peak of the ridge, white with Snow, which the Gentlemen who accompanied us said must have fallen yesterday— We then went and visited a party of Indians from Canada—St. Francis Indians, who had pitched their Tents, in an open field near the Village— There were two or three families, men, women and children, remnants of a larger number, fifty or sixty who had been here several days, and had departed a few days since— They looked very miserable; but had some stuffs of their own fabrics which they sold at excessive prices— I purchased for 3 1/2 dollars a pair of Mocassins worth perhaps 50 Cents. Five or six Gentlemen of Littleton, invited themselves to dine with us and insisted upon giving us the dinner, to which we consented— The Revd. Mr Fairbanks the Minister of the place was also invited and dined with us.— We left Littleton at 2 O’Clock P.M—with the waggon and pair driven by Mr Gibb, our host, and came to Ethan Allen Crawford’s, at Hart’s Location, 20. Miles— The road was almost a continual ascent without steep hills; through a forest, chiefly of Hemlock and Mountain Ash—the Maples having dwindled into shrubs, and the Oaks and Walnuts having disappeared.— We saw some wild pigeons and a few blue jays, but the scarcity of birds is one of the most remarkable characteristics of these woods. A beautiful young Buck came close up to the road—looked very steadily at us, and then turned round, and galloped away— We arrived at Crawford’s just in time to see the Sunset beautifully clear— We met at the Inn a party consisting of Mrs Charles Paine, two Mrs. and two Misses Greenough; and a boy. Dr Edward Warren, Mr Humphreys, and two young men by the name of Weld— The Evening was cold, and we all sat round a large fire except Mrs. Davis who retired early to bed— Mr Crawford keeps a Swivel, below his barn, and nearly opposite to his house; with which he fires an Evening gun, the report of which is repeated five or six times by successive Echo’s.
3. V. Tuesday— From E. A. Crawford’s through the Notch to Conway.

My Chronometer stopp’d at 3. A.M. with the cold.— I rose soon after five. It was then broad day light with the sky perfectly clear— Crawfords Thermometer which had hung over night, outside the door was at 28— From a knowl below Crawford’s barn, where he keeps his Swivel Mr Davis and I saw the Sun rise in Cloudless Majesty, as if issuing directly from the Peak of Mount Washington— Since the day when I saw the Sun rise from the Riesenkoppe in Silesia, I had not viewed so sublime a sight. Crawford fired his Morning Gun, the echoes of which reverberated more distinctly than they did last Night— Immediately after breakfast the four young Men of Mrs Paine’s party started with a guide, all on horseback, for the summit of Mount Washington— I felt a strong inclination to join them, but recollecting my state of health and my age, I refrained from the undertaking— Thirty three years have passed since I ascended the Silesian Mountains, and “non sum qualis eram.” Mr and Mrs Davis and I left E. A. Crawford’s with
the same waggon, horses and driver, which had brought us from Littleton, very soon after the young men, and came through the Notch to Thomas Crawford’sMiles— The weather continued fair but had moderated, and the Thermometer was at 60. ThenMiles to Abel Crawford’s, the father— ThenMiles to Goulds in the Town of Bartlett. About Noon we visited the Cottage, where the Willey family perished, in the slide, or Avalanche of 28 August 1826.— The Notch is a remarkable curiosity, perhaps half a mile long; the rocks on both sides being so steep and precipitous to an elevation of about 2000 feet that the look as they had been ruptured by the convulsions of an Earthquake— The trees are Wild Cherries black and red Mountain Ash—large hemlock, Maples dwindled into shrubbery, but neither Oaks nor Walnuts Gould married the daughter ofHall, formerly a Member of Congress, who kept this house We came to Gould’s at 1. P.M. dined and remained there till 5. waiting for the Stage from Concord to take us up— I took the occasion to write a Letter to my wife— Mr Davis was suddenly seized with a Chill, just as we left Abel Crawford’s, and it was succeeded by a smart fever he went to bed at Gould’s, but was better towards Evening.— At 5. the Stage took us up. Mr Gibb and his waggon and pair having already left us to return home to Littleton— We came 16 Miles to Conway. We had several transient fellow passengers, and arrived at Conway, about 8 in the Evening, just after fording Saco river in the dark— In this we had no difficulty although the waters, raised by the rains had been yesterday so high as to be scarcely fordable at-all— At Conway we met two young men from Boston— One of them a Painter; going to the White Mountains for Scenery.
4. III.30. Wednesday.

At four of the Morning we departed from Conway in the Stage, with new fellow Passengers—Strangers. 12 Miles to an indifferent Breakfast at Eaton— Then 18 Miles to Centre Harbour at the head of the Lake. Here at 11. we embarked in the Steamer Belknap; and traversing the Lake, landed at 1/2 past 2. and dined about 2 miles distant from the landing, at Alton.— The lake is 20 miles long, and no where two Miles wide. There are said to be in it 365 islands.— We had numerous fellow-passengers of both sexes— One party from New-Orleans, travelling with their own Carriage— Mr Adams the Constructor of the Steam Engine in the boat.— Much smoke. John Phillips of Newbury-Port, with wife and child, both sick—Mr Dorr. Miss Susan Phillips—Miss Swett, and several other Ladies— We came 15. in and upon the Stage from Alton 24 Miles to Somersworth—a factory town— Here Mr and Mrs Davis and I stopped for the Night— The rest of our company went five Miles further to Dover— At all the houses from Newbury-Springs—at Bath—at Littleton—at the Iron factory house on the way to Franconia— At all the Crawford’s—at Gould’s, and onboard the Steamer Belknap They keep Album’s, in which the Travellers inscribe their names, their Nonsense and their wit— Precious little of the last. The travellers to the white mountains are numerous of late; and they are objects of real curiosity— The introduction of the Steamboat upon the Lake brings it from the unexplored savage state into the centre of civilization— It seems like exploring a new world.
5. V. Thursday.— Somersworth— Dover.

Sudden change of weather—and of the wind to Southwest— After Breakfast Mr Folsom, and Mr Hooper accompanied us, and we inspected the Carpet, the Broad cloth and the Cotton manufactories— There were several new Inventions, the chief of which was the Brewster with horizontal Spindles and perpendicular threads. Principal factory 204 feet long— Salmon-falls river— Weaving of the Carpets curious. We crossed the Bridge into the State of Maine The woollen manufactures very uncleanly—with the Air overheated and offensive smells. Bales of wool—picking—dying—spinning—carding—weaving—raising the nap from Teazle—from Connecticut and Ohio— Fulling and packing in Bales—border lists—Dye stuffs—Indigo. Cochineal—Madder—Logwood—Alum—Copperas—Steel machinery—all wrought here— Returning to the Inn, we found the Hunt and Howard party from New-Orleans, had taken possession of our parlour, with Adams the engine maker— Cleared out. I received a few visitors— Hooper dined with us— Walk after dinner up the Hill. Saw Mount Washington 90 Miles distant— Call at Mr Folsom’s. We took a Carriage and pair of Horses and came 5 Miles to Dover— Took lodgings at Wyatt’s. Judge Mellen and his Son Grenville, John Read, Dr Howe, Mrs Babcock, Mary-Ann Marshall, Judge Kent—Mr and Mrs Lathrop—Mr Williams, Mr Ely once of Haverhill and other visitors called upon us in the course of the Evening— The house was thronged.
6. V. Friday. Dover— Portsmouth

Mr Read’s party went this morning for Boston. Judge Mellen’s for Portland— Mr Curtis formerly of the United States Navy— We called at the house of the Revd. Mr Lathrop, settled here as Minister of a Unitarian Church— Visited the Cotton printing factory. Colouring—Mordant’s Bleaching— Extraordinary process of singeing by rolling the cloth over a red hot cylinder— Pressing—100 Tons to a square inch— Steel and copper cylinders— Designs of figures—drawing— English Artists most expert at designing— Muslin and Calicoes— Cocheco river. Its water at this time very scanty by reason of the drought— Falls over the rocks— Prospect from the top of the factory extensive and beautiful. Dr Belknap’s House is pointed out with reverence— Garrison-hill— Visited at Mrs Widow Atkinson’s—Portraits—Wife of John Wentworth—painted by Copley, in 1765—married Atkinson a fortnight after her first husband’s death— Miss Wendell received us. We dined at one O’Clock— Mrs Wyatt, wife of the keeper of the house, insisted upon seeing me, told me she admired my parting Address to La Fayette in 1825, and shewed me an engraved Print, by Longacre, from Stuart’s portrait of my father— After dinner we took a Coach and pair of Horses, and came 12 miles to Portsmouth— Crossed the Piscataway river and Bridge— Beautiful Prospect— Great and Little Agamenticus. Saw the Steeple of Newington Church, and the house where my father’s Uncle the third Joseph Adams, who was Minister of that Church about 60 years, lived— We arrived at Portsmouth about 4. O’Clock in the afternoon and took lodgings at Clark’s—a new house— Walk round the town— The houses of the sometime Governor Langdon, of Mrs Aylwin—of Jeremiah Mason, and of Daniel Webster were pointed out to our notice. Mr Upham the former collector of the Port, called upon us, and accompanied Mr Davis and me in another walk round the Town— The Son of Judge John Pickering also accompanied us. We visited the Athenaeum, and by invitation of Mr Upham spent the Evening at his house
with a numerous company of both sexes; among whom were besides Mr Upham’s family Mr Cushing—the Revd. Mr Burroughs, Minister of the Episcopal Church, Mr Purser Wilson and several Ladies— About 10 O’Clock we returned to our Inn.
7. V. Saturday Portsmouth— Boston

We left Portsmouth in the Stage, at 8 O’Clock this Morning— Passed through Hampton and Salisbury to Newbury-Port 20. Miles— There was a daughter of Captain Coombs, a traveller with us in the Stage. The Public House at Newbury-Port is on the site of that in which I lived nearly two years with Mrs Hooper— There was an hour of interval between the arrival of the Stage at Newbury-Port, and its departure for Boston; which hour I employed in visiting some of the haunts of my early youth, in this place, after forty-three years of absence from it— I found a new world, with relicks, yet fresh in my Memory, of what was there. Mr Hector Coffin took me to an exhibition of the horticultural Society, where there was a fine display of fruits and flowers— Coll. Colman took me, in a Gig round the Town— I marked the old ferry landing where I often bathed with my fellow Students Bridge and Foster, on Summer Evenings, with the full tide—and we went up through High-Street to the Newbury Meeting-House, where I was wont to hear the excellent Sermons of Doctor Tucker— He has long since gone to his reward, and the House has been rebuilt, so that I only recognized the Spot. Returning through High-Street, I saw the Tracy House with Timothy Dexter’s wooden Statues before it— Met separately Captain Farris and his wife Fanny Jenkins; and Colman reminded me of my Poem, the Vision in which she was introduced— He pointed her out to me as she was walking in the Street but I had no opportunity to speak to her. The houses of Theophilus Parsons my instructor in Law and of Moses Frazier were shewn me— On returning I paid a short visit to the Revd. Dr John Andrews, and saw his wife, whom I had known, as Miss Wigglesworth, and their two grown up daughters. Before the Inn I met Mr Benjamin Gorham—casually there—and a man who shewed me a receipt dated 4. August 1789. for 8 dollars, received by me from a man named Foster, for Theop Parsons.— At Noon the Stage again started, and we came over the Turnpike road through Newbury and Rowley— Dined at Ipswich— Then came through Hamilton, Wenham, Beverley, Salem, Lynn, Chelsea, and Charlestown, to Boston, where we landed at 6. P.M. at Mr Davis’s house; and there at the door met his Son Thomas—with a message from my wife that she had been in town this day. I walked to my Son Charles’s house N. 3. Hancock Avenue— He returned there from Quincy with his family this morning— My wife had returned to Quincy at 5 this afternoon. I went again to Mr Davis’s, and settled with him for the expenses of our Journey, which amounted to 134.84. I paid him 50 dollars for my portion— Mrs Davis’s mother Mrs Jackson was there. Mrs J. W. Davis her daughter, and William Sturgis. I returned to Charles’s House for the Night.
8. V. Sunday Boston— Quincy

Breakfasted at my Son Charles’s. John Kirk came in for me with a Gig immediately after we had done breakfast. I went to Mr Davis’s and Kirk came and took me up there. Came home to Quincy, where blessed be God I found all my family well.
I arrived after the morning Service had begun— Attended public worship in the afternoon—heard Mr Barrett of Boston—a Son of Samuel Barrett who formerly resided in this town— His text was from Luke 14.18. “And they all with one consent began to make excuse.” an argumentative discourse in successive refutation of the various excuses commonly offered for not taking an interest in religion— The reasoning good— The delivery of the Sermon, animated— That of the prayer cold, but short— I read the 7th. Sermon of the 4th volume of Saurin on the indispensable obligation of entire devotedness to the divine Laws. The text is from James 2.10. “For whosoever shall keep the whole Law, and yet offend in one point, he is guilty of all.” The preacher appears to be much perplexed with his text, and says this Epistle might be called the paradoxes of Saint James. He qualifies very largely the general assertion of the text, and exposes with great ingenuity the sense in which he understands it— John and Mary spent the Evening at Daniel Greenleaf’s, and Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams were here.
9. IV:30. Monday.— O curas hominum! O quantum est in rebus inane!

I had flattered myself on returning from my recent excursion to have enjoyed recruited health, and to have devoted myself for the remainder of the Season with assiduity to my appropriate labours— But on visiting my garden and nursery this morning I found myself unable to work and perceived a languor and debility which increased upon me the whole day— I was however not totally disabled from writing a few lines. Deacon Spear was here, with Mr Charles Baxter.— The Deacon has been confined to his house by indisposition these four Months, but hopes he is now recovering. He spoke about the sale of wood on the remainder of my woodlots in this town; which he proposed to me to view, with his brother, William—to which I agreed— The Deacon spoke also of the antiquities, and genealogies of the town of Quincy; and told me that my father had related to him the anecdote of the manner how my name came be John Quincy— It was the name of my maternal great grandfather. I was born on Saturday the 11th. of July 1767. my mother’s mother, Elizabeth Smith, wife of William Smith, Minister of the first Parish of Weymouth, was with my mother at the time of my birth— Her father John Quincy was on his death-bed; and she requested that his name might be given to me, which it accordingly was on Sunday the 12th. of July. My Great-grandfather died the next Morning, in the 79th. year of his age— Mr Beale was here this Evening, and presented me a vote of the parish at their adjourned meeting last Monday accepting my proposal to take the 30 remaining pews in payment of the debt of 3000 dollars due to me by the parish. He had also a statement—shewing that a Settlement has been made with the pew holders, who had made past payment before, and that provision has been completed, for paying all the rest of the parish debt by a subscription the greatest part of which has been already collected.
10. VI. Tuesday.

I was twice up in the night, and this whole day in a state of prostration of strength, unable to put pen to paper, and consequently in a dejection of mind which almost made life a burthen— It was the birthday of my Son John’s wife, and also of his youngest daughter Georgiana Frances, who this day three years ago was born, at this house— We had invited our friends to dine with us; and
I had hoped to share joy on this occasion— But I was obliged to leave the table, and passed nearly the whole day upon my bed. Yet the judgment that I bear is in mercy. I suffer no pain but am in a state of lassitude, unable to hold up my head, to stand upon my feet, or to sit up in a chair. The powers of the mind are proportionally debilitated— I could only lie upon my bed and read, without taking any pleasure in reading, and scarcely forming a reflection upon what I read.— Mrs Adams sent for Dr Holbrook, who came and prescribed an emetic of Ipecacuanha for to-morrow Morning, and a Cathartic of Rhubarb and Castor Oil for the next day— This disease of debility is ashamed of itself. Suffering no severe pain, I feel as if I ought to be occupied, and cannot realize the imbecility which disqualifies for action I read several Odes of Horace which I never could understand—particularly the 17th. of the first Book, to Tyndaris. Yet nothing can be more beautiful than the Union of Philosophy, Sentiment, and picturesque description in most of the Odes of Horace— No Translation can do them Justice.
11. VI. Wednesday.

Conforming to the Prescription of Doctor Holbrook I took this morning an emetic of Ipecacuanha, which had one mild operation, and kept me in a state of debility all the morning of the day, and part of the afternoon. It is like the Talisman of an Arabian Tale, and seems to strip a man of all his Sinews— I wasted most of this day in reading Buckingham’s English Parliamentary Register—four numbers of which were lent me by Mr I. P. Davis. It is a miscellany containing merely an abstract of the debates in the reformed Parliament with much other matter. The reform does not appear to have improved the character of the House of Commons. There are new Speakers, but none who acquire much influence over the house— None who take away the lead from the principal Orators of the preceding times— Mr Williams the Collector of Taxes was here, and I paid him the balance of my last years Tax. I gave him also an order upon G. W. Beale, the Parish Treasurer for 180 dollars, the amount of one year’s interest on the Note due from the Parish to me, with 70 Cents additional which barely pays my parish-tax for the present year. I have submitted to the iniquity of these Assessments, rather than to have recourse to the decision of Courts of Law, upon a system so constituted that it would be a mere Lottery ticket, whether I should not lose it on both sides, against the Assessors and against Spear.
12. VI. Thursday.

My emetic of yesterday was succeeded this morning by a table spoonful of Castor oil, mixed up with a teaspoonful of tincture of Rhubarb. This finished the first part of my remedial course of Physic: and the second commenced this Evening, with a small pill of Calomel, Opium and Ipecacuanha, each one grain which I am to take nightly for 8 or ten days— So directed by Dr Holbrook who was here this afternoon. I was up once last night and have been recruiting in Strength all this day: began again to write Charles came out from Boston and dined with us. Immediately after dinner Pliny Merrick, Henry Gassett and Seth Whitmarsh a Committee from the State Anti-masonic Convention which met yesterday at Boston
came out and Mr Merrick presented to me three Resolutions of the Convention, the last of which was a unanimous nomination of me to be Governor of the Commonwealth for the ensuing year. I had done every thing in my power to prevent this, which is an exceedingly unwelcome movement to me; but it was placed upon grounds which left me no honourable option of declining. So I concluded on reflection. I promised the Committee to have my answer transmitted to them by ten O’Clock, to-morrow morning, and they took their leave— I sent my answer by Charles who returned this Evening to Boston. I accept the nomination, which casts me again upon the stormy ocean of political electioneering when I hoped and believed I was snug in the Port. If there be a fatality that pursues me, there is a Power above by whom it is guided— I cannot speak my forebodings but [symbols]
13. VI. Friday

Fine cool weather after a rainy afternoon yesterday, and a frost last Night. I returned to labouring in my garden, and cleared two avenues between the Rasberry bushes, of almost a waggon load of weeds; most of which have grown up from two to seven feet high since the first of July. I was between two and three hours at work. Deacon Savile came with a Petition to the Selectmen to widen the road near the Meeting-house, which he wished me to sign— I declined at present on a doubt of the right of the Selectmen, by Law, to widen a road by their mere authority— I promised to consider of the proposal, and enquire into the Law. Solomon Thayer brought two old Documents, shewing his military service and pay at 20 dollars a month, with a view to having his Pension increased— I advised him to authenticate them as original papers, by Oath before a Magistrate, and promised then to transmit them with a recommendation to the Secretary of War— He promised also to come and sow for me next Tuesday an Acre of his Ray wheat— He says he reaped 41 bushels from the half-Acre which I saw. I went this evening with my Son John to a party at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s, and a supper of fruits and cakes, and wine to which I staid, but John came home before supper. I had conversation with several persons upon my recent excursion to the white mountains, and with some of the Quincy’s upon an old Letter from Edmund Quinsey dated in 1712. which I received this day from C. Burroughs at Portsmouth. He had mentioned it to me when I saw him there, as being in his possession, and promised to send it to me. My Son John’s wife has for the last three days been confined to her chamber with a cold and fever.
14. VI. Saturday

I cannot yet return to my interrupted course of Life, and all my regular occupations run in arrear—above all, my diary which I cannot even keep up with the current of time— Mr Beale brought me the Deeds of 30 Pews in the Stone Meeting house 15 in one deed, and 15 other several Deeds— I am to examine them and finding them correct, to give up the Note of the parish to me— I hear my Grandchild Mary-Louisa, from 2 to 3 hours every day, learning her Letters. If the employment is not dignified it is necessary, honest, and at least not a waste of time. These are my only consolations— May the blessing not be withdrawn— My wife went to Boston this afternoon, and returned home this Evening— Charles came out here and went back. I weeded the third alley between the rows of Rasberries and found a row thickly sown of white Mulberry trees, just up from the seeds which I planted in July—but not one of my Strawberries
has come up. That experiment as invariably happens with those on which I place any reliance, has totally failed and it is so late in the Season, that I cannot expect any of my white mulberries will survive the Winter. The hickory pignuts planted last Autumn, still continue to shoot up from the surface of the ground— I found two or three just appearing this day— I had two stumps of Old Peach trees dug up by my workman Walter, and taken away. Yet remnants of the Roots were left in the ground. As they were they reminded me too much and too often of my own Condition. Dead to all useful purpose, but presenting a permanent ruin to the eye, and occupying by its mere existence a place which might be filled by young, healthy and profitable Plants— Miserere mei Domine. (N.B. 21 June 1835. The querulous tone of this day’s record was written in no becoming Spirit, under the pressure of disease, disappointment, and melancholy forebodings— A Christian should endure with fortitude and resignation all the ills of life, and never lose his trust in a superintending Providence— The failure of my planting experiments, trifles lighter than air grates upon my feelings, by the train of associated ideas linked with the purposes and hopes of life— My white mulberries were all killed by the succeeding winter, because they were sown too late— The Strawberries all came up in the Spring of 1834. and in the Summer of 1835 are exterminated by an invasion of self-sown clover— The great difficulty of raising Hickory trees, arises from the lateness of the Season when they come up— The stem has not time to ripen before the killing frost comes. Patience and a mind fortified against disappointment are indispensable to a raiser of seedling trees. He must always remember the story and moralize to his own improvement the Story of Jonas and his gourd)
15. VI. Sunday.

I found my health amended— Heard Mr Presbury, a young man whom I had never before seen— His morning Sermon was from Luke 15.31. “And he said unto him, Son, thou art ever with me, and all that I have is thine,” upon that most admirable parable of the Prodigal Son. Considered in a point of view different from that which is most usual. That is, he urged the preferable condition of the virtuous and industrious brother, who needed not forgiveness, and had nothing of which to repent— The text of the afternoon was from 1. John 1.9. “If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.” Mr Whitney was in the Pulpit the whole day, and gave notice that Mr Lucius Manlius Sargeant would deliver an Address, at 7. O’Clock this Evening at the Railway Church. I read the 8th. and 9th. Sermons of the fourth Volume of Saurin, sur les Travers de l’Esprit humain. Upon the persversities of the human mind— There is no word in the English Language corresponding exactly with the French word Travers, as here used— Cross-grained is the nearest approximation to it— The Sermons themselves are admirable; and there is a third upon the same Subject. The preacher as in many other cases perplexes himself with difficulties too mighty for him to solve, and he is again haunted by the Spirit of Bayle, whom he vituperates in one passage, and quotes with approbation in another. Saurin is evidently shackled with his own Articles of Faith. My wife and Mary took tea, at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. She returned last Evening from Medford, where she has been nursing her daughter, Mrs Angier, ill with a bilious fever.
I spent the Evening at Coll. Quincy’s— Mrs Joseph Russell and her daughter Miss Gore, were there.
16. V:45. Monday

I am beginning to return to my accustomed occupations, and was between two and three hours in my Garden and Nursery eradicating weeds and making preparation for planting nuts, acorns, stones and seeds— I teach my Grand daughter to read, and resume the daily minutes of reading in Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint Bible— Mr and Mrs Bailey paid us a morning visit— I finished making a copy of the Letter from Edmund Quinsey of Brantrey 29. December 1712 to John Quinsey in England, which I received from the Revd. C. Burroughs— The writer was the third Edmund Quincy—the judge and Agent of the Province in England, born 24. October 1681. and who died of the smallpox in London 23d. February 1737. There is an endorsement upon it by another Edmund Quincy dated London. 20. Novr. 1772, and styling the Letter his grandfather’s. This last Edmund Quincy must have been a brother of Mrs Hancock, and son of the Edmund Quincy who since my memory was a judge of the Court of Common Pleas in Boston, and an acting Justice of Peace— The repetition of the same Christian name in families through successive generations breeds confusion— Why is it that in the English Language there are no words expressive of filiation but father and Son—Mother and daughter— The Latin has avus and nepos, Proavus, abavus, atavus and Tritavus. Six degrees ascending. The French have ayeul, bisayeul, trisayeul four degrees ascending— The English has only the adjunct grand added to father or Son indiscriminately for the second degree up or down, and then the compound adjunct great, added to grand, and repeated as many times over as there are degrees— So that the Roman Tritavus is in English Great, great, great, great Grandfather. Thus Henry Adams, the first founder of my family in this Country was the Tritavus of my Sons, and the first Edmund Quincy was Tritavus to me and Atavus to President Quincy.— The appropriation of specific names to the remote relations of descent indicates a people devoted to family attachments— Barbarous nations have no genealogies. My wife and my Son John fished this morning for Smelts, and we played in partie quarrée this Evening a rubber of whist.
17. VI. Tuesday.

My wife and my Son John went upon a fishing excursion this Morning. Mrs Adams returned unwell— Mr Beale was here, and I delivered up to him the Note from the Parish Treasurer to me for 3000 dollars; in payment of which I have taken the 30 pews, which had remained unsold. It is to me extremely burdensome as a tax, and teaches me what I ought to have known without needing the admonitions of experience: that the warmest and the best of feelings require the steady guidance of discretion— I spent two hours of the morning in my garden and Nursery. The Seedlings of the year which have survived the drought are now preparing to meet the frost of winter. A very great proportion of them have perished— The dwarf Apple is just now ripe, and a very fine fruit. The growth of weeds is gigantic— I employed much of my time in writing. My scriptural minutes of the morning; and Diary minutes— Copy of a Deed in the Manuscript Book of Documents relating to the Execution of my father’s Will, and part of an answer to a Letter from R Walsh Teaching also my Grand daughter to read—a trying School of Patience to myself. In the evening we played a rubber of whist— A late Scottish traveller in this Country named Hamilton who
visited me at Washington, introduced by Mr B. O. Tayloe has published a Book entitled Men and Manners in America— He announces that the standard of morality in the United States is low. That the Scot is a much more honest man than the Yankee. That there are no Jews in New-England—and that from their puritan descent the New-Englanders have a double portion of intellect and only half a heart.— There are certainly no Sir Archy M’Sarcasms or Sir Pertinax M’Sycophants in New-England— They are all of Scottish breed and well suited to travel in America, and furnish books of men and manners for the London market.
18. V:15. Wednesday.

My wife was confined to her chamber the whole day. Mary went with her two children to Boston; dined at Charles’s and returned home this Evening— The weather threatened a storm, and there was a very little rain. Not enough to soak the ground. Solomon Thayer was here, and brought his old Journal of 1776 and the payroll of his company commanded by Captain Edward Boylston to prove that his pay was 20 dollars a Month, and to obtain an increase of his Pension which has been granted to him only at the rate of 8 dollars a Month. He belonged to a company of Artificers in three divisions of 25 men each, Wheelwrights, Blacksmith’s and Carpenters— He was of the company of Wheelwrights, and transported two large Mortars from Boston to Fort Washington in New-Jersey. He has made oath to his documents before Minott Thayer, and I am to write for him to the Secretary of War. He brought me some of the large Woolaston Apples, and sowed for me about three quarters of an Acre of ground on the hill opposite my house, with his new grain which John thinks is cheat— I count 80 of my paces by 20 to an Acre— A young man by the name of Rawson was here this afternoon: a Student at Yale College, travelling on foot to Plymouth. He stopped here from curiosity, and chiefly to enquire his way. I began the attempt to retrieve the arrears of my Diary since my excursion to the White Mountains. Attempted to finish my Letter to R. Walsh, but was unable— From the time Evening came on I was alone, but could neither read nor write, for drowsiness.
19. IV:15 Thursday.

Mr French of Randolph came and spoke to me of a small piece of Land, about 3. Acres, taxed in the town of Randolph to the heirs of John Adams; said to have been a part of the Estate of Norton Quincy, and which French says has been this Summer sold for the payment of taxes—by a man named Shadrach Turner, the Collector for the present year; he supposes to gratify his Masonic Resentments— French was himself the Collector for the year 1830, and the tax was then six Cents— That of the present year must have been about as much— I have never been able to find either the Land or the evidence of title to it— I proposed to call upon Mr French, next Saturday afternoon at four O’Clock to make further enquiry concerning it. He says he has land adjoining to it, and proposes to give me five or ten dollars for a Quit-claim Deed. Mr Downes brought a subscription book for the projected publication by Jared Sparks of the works of George Washington, in eight or twelve volumes; and I subscribed for one copy— There was a great and sudden change of weather from autumnal frost to the sultry
heat of dog-days— My wife continues confined to her chamber— I received a Letter from my old friend Christopher Hughes, just returned from Europe, at New-York, and one from Mrs Maria Brooks with her Poem of Zophiel or the bride of seven, which she has at last received from London— My garden labours are suspended by the heat—
20. V. Friday.

The equinoctial is at hand, and there was yesterday slight rain, and this Evening the fragment of a Thunder shower. The sultriness of the weather prevented me from working in my garden and Nursery— I finished this morning the minutes of my reading the Book of Esther in Charles Thomson’s translation of the Septuagint, and answered the Letters of Mrs Maria Brooks, R. P. and C. Williams, and George P. Morris. I have great difficulty in retrieving the arrears of my Diary and correspondence, and have scarcely time for reading any thing but Newspapers— This afternoon my wife and Mary went to Boston, and being detained by the Thunder-Shower, returned late this Evening—about ten— I walked at the dusk of Evening to the 6th. Mile Stone, and back for exercise— Of my Seedling Plantations, one Nectarine and six Peach trees bear this year for the first time— On the day of my return from the white mountains, my Son John sent five of the Nectarines to the Horticultural Society’s exhibition, and they were fine. The Peaches are all of small size, but all good of their kinds. None remarkable. The dwarf Apple tree bears this year perhaps a peck of excellent red Apples about the size of a Pearmain— Many of my wintered walnuts planted last May have come up— But none of the wintered Ohio Walnuts. No cherry Stones and no Strawberries. The failure of these I attribute to the drought. This has also been my reason for the forbearance as yet to plant my Peach and Plum Stones, and Apple and Pear-Seeds.— The time for planting Acorns, and Walnuts, and most Stone fruits is the month of October— If planted in the Spring, it is so late in the Summer before they come up, that they have not time to harden for the first Winter’s frost— This is the greatest trial of all seedling trees in this climate— But insects and field mice and Squirrels, and the Summer Sun, and drought, and strangling weeds are also deadly enemies to them— A tree is as hard to raise as a child.
21. V. Saturday.

Showery Night and Morning; but without much rain— The drought is deep, and most of the Springs in the neighbourhood are failing. I planted one row in the garden, and one in the Nursery, on the North and west side of the fence, of Peach and Plum Stones and Apple seeds with six whole Apples. Found two of the fairest looking of the wintered walnuts which had come up killed by the Sun or heat of the last four days— After dinner I took my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa with me, and rode to Mr Zenas French’s at East Randolph. He went with me and shewed me the two pieces of swampland, about three Acres in the whole, which have been sold for payment of a tax amounting to less than half a dollar, assessed in my name—but as French says, being part of the Estate of Norton Quincy, and of course not mine. The Collector’s name who sold the Land is Shadrach Thayer— French says he told him that he had advertised the Sale in the Centinel and that he had called at my house to notify me; but I never saw the advertisement, nor heard of the man’s calling. The purchaser’s
name is Turner. The charges of Sale about 7 dollars— The Assessor who palmed it upon me, a Selectman of the year before last, named Jonathan Blanchard; and the Selectman, and Assessors of the present year are Henry Bass, Alden Spear; and Jonathan White— We passed by the house of my Cousin John Adams, built by his father Elihu as I then thought at the end of the world. When we got home this Evening I found that my Son Charles had been here this afternoon, and that my wife was gone with him into Boston— Charles’s wife is in hourly expectation of being confined. [symbols]
22. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney this morning from 1. Samuel 3.18. “And he said— It is the Lord— Let him do what seemeth him good.” An occasional discourse on the Death of Elijah Spear, though without any special allusion to him. The afternoon Sermon was from Revelation 15.3. “And they sing the song of Moses, the Servant of God, and the song of the Lamb; saying great and marvellous are thy works, Lord God Almighty: just and true are thy ways, thou king of Saints.” I lost the reading of a Sermon of Saurin. Mr Degrand walked out from Boston and dined with us. About Sunset I rode with him as far as the South Boston Bridge, and there he alighted and returned home— I came back without going further, into the City, and received a warning of disappointment and humility— Degrand told me of the National Republican party Meeting last Friday to confirm the delegation from Boston, to the Worcester Convention to be held on the 2d. of October, to nominate Candidates for the Offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the ensuing year: and of Resolutions proposed by Eastburn, publisher of the Atlas which were set aside— Mr Thomson the Steam doctor, with his Agent Mr Brown was here this afternoon— He wishes to obtain a new Patent for his Botanical Medicines, with improvements, and he asked for my assistance next Winter at Washington, which I promised him, so far as I could with propriety. He offered me compensation which I declined. Mr Beale, Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams were here this Evening.— Charles’s Son born
23. IV:45. Monday.

William Spear was here this morning, and I agreed to go with him, next Thursday if fair, or the next fair day, to see the lots of wood of mine to be sold this year. Charles came out from Boston, but returned home to dine and took Mrs Kirk with him. His mother was seized yesterday morning with a sudden and violent illness, and last night about ten minutes before twelve O’Clock his wife was delivered of a Son— Judgment and Mercy! A feeling of awful solemnity mingles with my emotions at the concurrence of these Events— How deep an admonition of the frailty of human purposes at the illness of my wife, at the very moment when her aid was needed, and which she had expressly gone into Boston to bestow! and what a new world of humble hope is opened before me, which I had for some time not dared to anticipate, amidst the misfortunes and sorrows which have befallen me in the last four years! I know not how to order my Speech aright: but pour forth my heart and Soul in [symbols]
Alexander H. Everett was here this afternoon— The Masonic faction in Boston, are in complete combustion at the Anti-Masonic nomination for Governor. The Atlas and Courier have published extracts from my Letter to B. Cowell with an outcry of proscription. Everett had a Letter written to me, asking for a developement of my views, disclaiming this proscriptive Spirit— I told him of my Letter, declining the Antimasonic nomination of 1831. and read to him the whole of my Letter to Cowell— He asked me for copies of them, but after much reflection, I thought it best to answer his Letter. I wrote the answer this Evening after he was gone. The National Republicans of Boston have elected 63 delegates to the Worcester Convention. 35 of whom are free masons; and the National Republicans in Berkshire have nominated Henry Shaw. There may probably be half a dozen Candidates, and no election by the People.
24. VI. Tuesday.

Planted a row of whole Nursery Crab Apples in the Garden between the rows of Strawberry Plants, and another in the Nursery at the central border, and one next below the Peach tree first Eastward of the gate. Spent some time in weeding— Sent John Kirk into Boston with the Carriage for Mrs Adams, but he returned without her—much discomposed— Dr Stephenson who attends her, thought it not safe for her to come out— Kirk was not visible for the remainder of the day after he came out. Mr James H. Foster was here this afternoon; having come with his wife to see her Sister Louisa Smith at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and who is unwell. Mr Foster consulted me with regard to making his Will— He had drawn up three Articles respecting the disposal of his real Estate, which he requested me to assist him in reducing to legal and technical form. He left the Paper with me— I walked about Sunset to the sixth Mile-stone for exercise— I am somewhat apprehensive that weeding and garden labour does not absolutely serve the purpose of a substitute for walking: and am indeed almost desponding of any good result from these labours. In that of bodily exercise I had undoubting confidence, and yet has it greatly failed— The infirmities of old age may be delayed, but must come sooner or later, and exercise and even temperance can secure health only for a Season— My journal and Correspondence continue to run in arrear, but I wrote a short answer to a Letter from John Howard Payne and began a long one to Christopher Hughes— My Son John was this day somewhat unwell. His health has been drooping nearly for the last two years, and my concern for him, is the deepest and most distressing of all my afflictions.
25. IV.45. Wednesday.

My Son John continued quite unwell, the whole of this day— I laboured in my Garden and Nursery, morning and afternoon— Planted in front of my chamber windows South of the house, a Stone of E. Cruft’s late Apricot, with Pears, Peaches, Apples and Plums. (N.B. 24. June 1835. Neither Mr Cruft’s Apricot, nor any of the Plum Stones came up; but two of the Peaches, several of the Pears, and one of the Apples did, and are undergoing various experiments— After surviving two winters some of them can scarcely fail to survive me. So long as I pass my Summers here, they may be always under my eye, and I may indulge the hope, not presumptuously but in humility that some of my children and grand-children may live to taste the fruits which they will bear. I fix the day here on which the
seeds were sown and the stones were planted) I planted also in the Garden a row of whole Officetree Apples, and in Pot N. 2, which I emptied and refilled with Earth from the Garden a whole dwarf-tree Apple in the Centre, 2 Canada Plum stones, and 6 cherries [symbols] Almost all my seedling Apple-trees in the garden and Nursery, come from the Office tree, or the dwarf tree, which I believe bears the same fruit— I have been able to identify no other— The remainder of the day was devoted without interruption to labour—reading and writing, with the lessons of reading to my grand-child Mary Louisa— A Message came by Mr Beale from my Son Charles to John Kirke to go into Boston to morrow morning at 6 O’Clock to exchange our old Carriage for a new one built by Knowles— I had received a notification to attend a meeting of the historical Society at Noon; and determined to go to Boston myself. I make slow progress in reading Thomson’s version of the Book of Job, comparing it with that of King James’s Bible, and with Noyes’s recent Translation— The main design of the Book is to prove that the afflictions of the righteous, do not authorise the impeachment of the Justice of God— Satan is permitted by God to afflict Job for the trial of his virtue— But Job, his wife, his three friends and Elihu are all ignorant of the real cause of his afflictions— The friends rashly conclude that they are in punishment of some secret guilt.— His wife more rashly imputes it to divine injustice, and considers God as an evil Spirit— Job himself admits that his sufferings are evidence against his purity, but protests his innocence, and expostulates against his calamities— God himself speaking from the whirlwind reproves Job for his self-justification, and his murmurs; by contrasting his own almighty power with the importance of Job— But God severely censures Job’s friends, for their unjust inferences against him; and ends by restoring him to a double portion of the Earthly blessings of which Satan had deprived him It does not appear that Job ever knew what had passed between God and Satan—nor how it became known to any one— Hence the probability that the whole Story is an Allegorical parable. The questions discussed, are all settled before hand for the reader, who knows from the first that the afflictions of Job are not for his punishment, but for his trial. The question whether such a trial is consistent with divine Justice, remains for solution.
26. VI. Thursday. Boston— Quincy.

I went to Boston in the old Carriage— Mrs Brymer and Elizabeth Kirke were with me, and my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa. At my Son Charles’s house, I found my wife, slowly recovering from the sudden and violent illness, which she has had. Charles’s wife, in the milk fever of her confinement, which was for a few hours extremely severe and critical. Her boy weighed ten pounds and is a fine promising child. Mr Brooks saw him yesterday but not his daughter— I called at Mr A. H. Everett’s, and gave him a Letter which I wrote to John Brazier Davis in April 1832. instead of a copy of the parts of my Letter to Benjamin Cowell which he did not publish and which on reflection I declined giving because it would seem unkindness to the Anti-masonic party for me now to authorise its publication. Everett read to me an Article, which he had prepared for the Daily Advertiser, and which he had intended to have inserted as Editorial; but which he said Mr Hale declined to insert as such— He mentioned also that Mr Webster now saw great difficulties in
the confirmation of the Anti-masonic nomination, and that it was astonishing to observe the supineness of all party action here excepting among the Masons. He thought the Masonic power altogether unaccountable, considering in how low estimation it had been held before this controversy arose. I told him I thought it might easily be accounted for. The power had formerly operated without being seen; but it might be traced, to Isaiah Thomas of Worcester, and through him to Benjamin Russell, many years publisher of the Boston Centinel— They were Printers, and made Fortunes, Thomas a very large one by their Types— They made free-masons of all their Apprentices and journeymen— The Masonic Oaths and mysteries give ten fold power to the knot of association, and by the secresy vital to the Institution, it became a conspiracy of exclusive privilege to the members at the expense of all the rest of the community— I attended the meeting of the Historical Society which was soon adjourned— Mr Snelling was appointed to prepare a memoir of Dr Redford Webster recently deceased. I dined at my Son Charles’s and soon after came home with my Grand child in the new Carriage— I attended an Evening party at Mr Edward Miller’s.
27. V:15 Friday

I went into the woods of the 600 Acres lots, with William Spear, to view those where Sales of the standing wood are to be made. The weather was fair. the sky clear— The atmosphere cool, an exquisitely beautiful autumnal day. We were out nearly six hours, from eight in the morning till near two in the afternoon. We visited the Borland lot, the wood from about two thirds of which was sold, and cut off last Winter—the Quincy lot, and the three half trees lot— Part of the ground over which we went was so thickly overgrown with bushes that it was with great difficulty we got through— We came out of the woods westward of the lot which I purchased last year of James Baxter, and there I saw Cattle said to belong to a man named David Thayer, grazing. There were sundry breaches in the Wall upon the road, which I engaged Mr Spear to repair next Winter, and I directed the wood remaining on the lot and the three others to be sold— Seven years have now passed away, since I first traversed these rocky woodlands, the autumn after the decease of my father—and I deeply felt this day the departure of my bodily strength in those seven years. My warnings, solemn warnings, daily return. Would that they might produce upon me their proper effect! I came home to dine. Mr and Mrs Cruft were here to visit us after dinner, and about Sunset my wife came home from Boston— John Kirke had been sent with the Carriage for her this morning— She brought out with her my Son Charles’s daughter Louisa-Catherine, and her Nurse, Mrs Field— The child is unwell—breeding teeth.
28. IV.45. Saturday

Mr John Bailey was here this morning. He said the State Anti-Masonic Committee had a question of great difficulty before them, namely, whom they should nominate for the Office of Lieutenant Governor in the place of William Reed of Marblehead who has declined the nomination of the Convention. I thought they should make no new nomination, but permit the party to vote as every individual should please, or recommend to them to vote for the present Lieutt. Governor, according to the first nomination of the Convention itself— Mr Clark, the late Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States, and Mr Force of Washington City, came and dined with us. I had met them in the Street in Boston, on Thursday, and invited them— They are
travelling in this part of the Country to procure documents for a compilation relating to the History of our Revolutionary War— They made some enquiries concerning the nomination of General Washington as Commander in Chief of the American Armies, and I read to them the passage on that subject in my father’s manuscript biography, written by himself in 1802. This is one of the numerous incidents of our revolutionary history deemed so unimportant at the time when they happened, that no record of them public or private was made, and about which curiosity grows more intense from day to day— They become subjects of controversy, in which conjecture takes the place of evidence, and sometimes remain ultimately unsettled or become Articles of faith in conflicting political creeds— My Son Charles also came and dined with us. There is much agitation in the Public mind, about an order from President Jackson to withdraw the deposits of Public Monies from the Bank of the United States, and to place them in sundry State Banks—and about a paper read by him to the members of his Cabinet on the 18th. of this month, followed by the dismission of William J. Duane, and the appointment of Roger B. Taney as Secretary of the Treasury— Upon all which I take time for reflection— Charles returned this Evening to Boston.
29. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney this morning from Psalm 119.59 “I thought on my ways, and turned my feet unto thy testimonies”—urging the duty of self-knowledge and self-examination. And in the afternoon from Luke 17.20. “And when he was demanded of the Pharisees, when the kingdom of God should come, he answered them and said, the kingdom of God, cometh not with observation. 21. Neither shall they say, Lo here! or Lo there! For behold, the kingdom of God is within you.” Mr Whitney gave notice that the Communion would be administered next Sunday— After the morning Service Coll. Josiah Quincy said to me that a Letter from me to Coll John Brazier Davis had been published yesterday in the Daily Advertiser, with a Statement that it had been found among his papers. That he was Davis’s Administrator, and had all his papers; but had never seen that Letter, and did not know by whom it had been published— He had written a note to Mr Hale to make enquiry on the subject. I told him that it was found in a draw of his writing desk, sold after his decease, and was now published with my assent.— It is the Letter which I gave to Alexander H. Everett at his request I told him the manner in which it was returned to me after the death of J. B. Davis, but he inconsiderately stated in publishing it, that it was found among Davis’s papers— Upon this Statement Coll. Quincy is called as Administrator to contest the fact, and permits himself to be used as an instrument for that honorable purpose— To make an issue upon the fact, whether I wrote a Letter, published with my assent—because he, the Administrator of the person to whom it was written had not seen it— So much for electioneering, and for Coll. Quincy’s Friendship Sense of Justice and Independence of Spirit. So much for the union of federalism and free-masonry. I read the 10th. Sermon of the 4th. Volume of Saurin; the third on the perversions of the human mind—and the first of the 5th volume on the Sunday before Christmas— His text is from Isaiah 9.5.6. The prophecy “Unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given:
and the government shall be upon his shoulder; and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, The Mighty God, The Everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace. Of the increase of his Government and Peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David, and upon his kingdom, to order with justice, from henceforth even forever.” He gives a historical exposition of this passage, and of the chapter from which it is taken, and the two preceding chapters.— He then argues its prophetic character as usual weakly answering strongly stated objections. The passage has been tortured by mistranslations, not only into a prophesy of Christ as the Messiah, but into a proof that Jesus is the Mighty God, and the everlasting Father— It is by no means certain that the passage has any reference to Christ whatever. I wrote to Jared Sparks, to Messrs. S. L. Armstrong and Pierpont, and to George A. Otis.
30. VI. Monday.

The drought continues, and a Midsummer Sun, pouring torrents of heat upon the atmosphere kept me from my Garden and Nursery, where the exercise of labour, under such a blaze is too potent for an enervated Constitution— I confined myself to the house, and resumed the teaching of the Alphabet to my Grand child. I finished reading the Book of Job, in Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint, and began the Psalms.— The descriptions of the Behemoth and Leviathan absorbed my attention— Neither of these animals is known, although one is supposed to be the Hippopotamos or river-horse, and the other the Crocodile. I read the Article of the Crocodile, in La Cepede’s Natural history; being the first Volume of the Serpents p. 259. among the Lizards— There are Crocodiles in Africa, Asia, North and South-America, but none in Europe. None in our part of America— After dinner I read a few Letters of Madame de Sevigné; and the first Book of Zophiel, or the bride of seven—Mrs Maria Brooks’s poem. Towards Evening I took a short walk on the Hill opposite to my house, to see if Solomon Thayer’s grain was up: but there is yet a very slight appearance of it if any— We had a rubber of whist in the Evening— My health is partially recovered, and a recent blessing of Heaven, sheds a last ray upon my hopes of the future as regards the present world— They have been too sanguine, and too fondly cherished— My mother had a mourning ring, on the death of my Sister Susanna, within which was engraved “Lean not on Earth: ’twill pierce thee to the heart”—a line from Young’s Night thoughts— I read it when a child, and it left upon my mind a deep impression— Yet it has not preserved me from leaning upon Earth— There is no Passion more deeply seated in my bosom, than the longing for posterity worthily to support my own and my father’s name I trace my Ancestors in the grave-yard and on the town Books to Henry Adams one of the first Settlers of the town of Braintree at Mount Wollaston— All I know of those of my fathers name untill him is that they were born, were married and died— He was eminent, and my desire has been that his name and his possessions here, should continue in his and his descendant’s name— For this I have done my part— My Sons must do theirs— There is now one Son of the next Generation, and my hopes revive— Is it a Sin, to implore the father of all Mercies, that his blessings of Wisdom and of Virtue may rest upon this child; upon others to succeed him and of upon all my children’s children?— Of future Sons, and daughters yet unborn?
